title.narrative: OUTPUT 3.2: COMMUNITIES' IMPROVED ACCESS TO Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH) SERVICES

description.narrative: New Element, which contributes to Children In Urban Settings / Local Governance, Environmental Sustainability, Sanitation, Sanitation (Covid), Water, Water (Covid). UNICEF aims to achieve this through Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, United Nations Working Together. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2024, children and their families in selected rural and urban areas, including in humanitarian settings, live in a climate- resilient environment and use safe and sustainable water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) services.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: New Element
Number of communities certified free of open defecation through institutional uptake (institutional uptake/indirect)
Proportion of externally verified ODF communities attributed to UNICEF support that maintain their ODF status for at least one year
Number of schools with Menstrual Hygiene Management implemented in schools programmes as a result of UNICEF direct support and/or leveraged through national programmes
Number of health centres (clinics, hospitals, etc.) equipped with WASH facilities in the reporting year only, as a result of UNICEF direct support [COVID] i) Basic water services

Number of health centres (clinics, hospitals, etc.) equipped with WASH facilities in the reporting year only, as a result of UNICEF direct support [COVID] iv) Basic health care waste management services
Number of health care facilities (clinics, health centers, hospitals, etc.) with basic WASH services in the reporting year only, as a result of through institutional uptake (leveraged)
Number of schools supported by UNICEF during the year of reporting with separate sanitation facilities for boys and girls
Number of additional people living in the newly certified Open Defecation Free (ODF) communities as a result of UNICEF CATS programming during the year of reporting
